title: Chinese and Russian leaders held a video conference to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations and discuss global strategic stability.
summary: According to Xinhua News Agency, on February 4, 2026, Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin held a video conference to jointly commemorate the 30th anniversary of the establishment of the China-Russia strategic partnership. During the talks, President Xi Jinping emphasized that in the face of the current turbulent international situation, deepening strategic cooperation between China and Russia is not only a necessity for bilateral relations but also a cornerstone for maintaining global strategic stability. President Putin highly praised the bilateral relationship as a "model" of cooperation between major powers, and particularly commended the strong resilience shown by China-Russia trade against the backdrop of Western sanctions. On the same day, Foreign Minister Wang Yi also met with Sergei Shoigu, Secretary of the Security Council of the Russian Federation, in Beijing. The two sides reached further understandings on implementing the consensus reached by the heads of state and supporting each other on core interests.

title: Russia and Ukraine resumed their second round of closed-door peace talks in Abu Dhabi, with significant territorial and sovereignty disputes remaining.
summary: According to the latest news received by this station, on February 4, 2026, with the active mediation of the United States, delegations from Russia and Ukraine officially began the second round of closed-door peace talks in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates. The Ukrainian delegation was led by Rustem Umerov, Secretary of the National Security Council. According to The New York Times, the core issues of this round of negotiations revolved around the status of eastern Ukraine and post-war security guarantees. Although the Trump administration had previously signaled that "the talks might make progress," both sides maintained a hardline stance. Putin insisted that Ukraine cede parts of the Donetsk region, currently under Ukrainian control, while Zelenskyy explicitly stated that he would never accept this. Furthermore, the Kremlin is hostile to any security agreements involving the presence of Western troops on Ukrainian territory, making the negotiation process still fraught with challenges.

title: The End of the Era of Nuclear Constraints? Two Days to Go Before the New START Treaty Between the US and Russia
summary: According to our station, the only remaining nuclear arms control treaty between the US and Russia, the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START), is scheduled to expire on February 5, 2026. The two sides have yet to reach a renewal or replacement agreement, raising strong concerns among global defense experts about a potential "vacuum" in nuclear force oversight. Reports indicate that once the treaty expires, bilateral on-site verification and data exchange mechanisms will completely cease. Analysis suggests that the US has the capability to increase its deployed nuclear warheads by 110% within months, while Russia could increase them by as much as 60%. This not only signifies a loss of transparency but could also trigger an uncontrollable global arms race in the absence of a dispute resolution mechanism.

title: Iran's Supreme Leader warns: US attack could trigger large-scale regional war
summary: According to reports from the Merkel News Agency and the Associated Press, Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei delivered a strongly worded speech on Sunday. Khamenei characterized the recent domestic protests as a premeditated "coup" and issued a clear warning to Washington, stating that any US military action against Iran would trigger an uncontrollable "regional war." Currently, the Iranian military has conducted a two-day live-fire exercise in the strategically vital Strait of Hormuz to demonstrate its military capability to blockade the waterway. Tehran emphasized that in the face of external threats, Iran will take all necessary measures to retaliate forcefully. This statement has instantly caused the risk of war in the Middle East to surge.

title: Sino-British relations officially "thawed": Starmer and Xi Jinping reached a consensus on a long-term partnership.
summary: According to our station, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer held a historic meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing on February 1, 2026. As the first British leader to visit China since 2018, Starmer's trip aimed to "reboot" bilateral relations. According to reports from The Guardian and the South China Morning Post, both sides agreed to establish a "more mature and long-term" comprehensive strategic partnership, shifting the focus to pragmatic economic cooperation. As a gesture of goodwill, China announced the lifting of previous restrictions on some British MPs, and British giants such as AstraZeneca subsequently announced major investment plans in China. Despite ongoing controversies within the UK regarding security issues, the British side expressed a desire to improve bilateral trade through soft power means such as "football diplomacy," and even opened the possibility of a future visit by a Chinese head of state to the UK.

title: The U.S. federal government has officially declared a partial shutdown due to a budget impasse.
summary: According to the latest news received by this station, the US federal government officially entered a partial shutdown in the early hours of January 31st local time because Congress failed to pass several key spending bills before Friday's midnight deadline. Bloomberg reported that although the Senate had previously passed the bills by a large majority, they failed to be enacted due to the early departure of House members from Washington. President Trump had previously warned that the shutdown would limit the functions of several government agencies. Currently, the White House is urging lawmakers to return on Monday and reconsider the bills to minimize their impact on the operation of the country. This deadlock reflects the serious domestic political challenges Trump faces during his term.

title: The Trump administration drastically reduced nuclear security requirements
summary: According to our station, the Trump administration completely rewrote its nuclear safety directive this month, reducing safety requirements for nuclear power plants. A Department of Defense spokesperson stated that this move aims to reduce operating costs, but Secretary of State Marco Rubio warned that the United States reserves the right to use force against Venezuela if interim president Delcy Rodriguez does not comply.

title: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio hinted at possible additional military action against Venezuela in the Senate.
summary: According to The Guardian, on January 28, U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, not ruling out the possibility of further military use in Venezuela. He noted that while there had been "significant progress" since Trump's "arrest" of Maduro on January 3, the situation remained highly uncertain. Facing sharp questioning from Democratic senators, Rubio acknowledged that the U.S. was still assessing its options for next steps.

title: The EU advances its secure satellite communications plan, with GOVSATCOM and IRIS² officially launched.
summary: According to the European Commission's daily press release, the EU announced today the launch of two key satellite projects: GOVSATCOM, providing secure government and military satellite links for all member states, and IRIS², which is scheduled to begin service in 2029. Both projects aim to reduce reliance on non-EU suppliers, enhance strategic autonomy, and build the EU's own secure connectivity network within the next decade.

title: More than 165 Russian drones attacked Odessa and other locations in Ukraine; Zelensky called for international pressure.
summary: According to UNN and The Independent, on January 27, 2026, Russia launched over 165 attack drones in a fierce assault on Odessa, Kharkiv, and other key Ukrainian cities. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky immediately called on the international community to exert maximum pressure on Russia to halt these attacks, which have caused widespread damage to civilian infrastructure and resulted in multiple casualties.

title: Trump announces Greenland negotiation framework, suspending February tariffs on Europe
summary: According to Malaysia's *The Star*, US President Trump announced in Davos on January 24th that he would suspend the tariffs originally scheduled for February 1st on eight European countries in exchange for progress on negotiations regarding Greenland's strategic status. While ruling out military intervention, Trump made it clear that the tariff reductions were directly linked to cooperation with NATO allies. French President Macron criticized the move as "coercive," and the EU has begun developing countermeasures, including in the agricultural and automotive sectors. Notably, the US plans to invest $25 million to upgrade the infrastructure of its military base in Greenland.

title: The first day of trilateral talks between the US, Russia, and Ukraine in Abu Dhabi ended without results, with territorial disputes remaining the core obstacle.
summary: According to Clash Report and Politico, on January 24-25, 2026, representatives from the US, Russia, and Ukraine held the first direct trilateral talks since the war broke out in Abu Dhabi, led by a special envoy of the Trump administration. The talks ended without results on the first day, with territorial disputes remaining the core obstacle. The talks will continue next week. Meanwhile, Russia launched large-scale airstrikes on Kyiv and other areas in Ukraine, causing civilian casualties and widespread power outages.

title: The European Union questions Trump's peace committee plan, claiming it may violate the UN Charter.
summary: According to our station, European Council President António Costa issued a formal statement on the 23rd, expressing deep concern over Trump's "Peace Commission" initiative launched at the Davos Forum the previous day. In his briefing following the informal EU summit, Costa pointed out that while the EU is willing to cooperate in the Gaza peace process, the commission's scope of authority and operating mechanisms are fundamentally in conflict with UN Security Council Resolution 2803. This statement directly responds to Trump's Davos declaration that "this body will benefit the UN." Documents disclosed concurrently with the meeting show that EU legal authorities are urgently assessing the commission's legal status.
